subject: Re: [junit] Test Everything, No Matter How Simple

messageBody:
On 8/22/06, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> On 8/22/06, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
> >
> > Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> >
> > > So you're recommending 100% code coverage?
> > >
> >
> > Yes.
>
>
> That's not very realistic, is it?

It depends. I actually favour 100% code coverage, but I'm going to put
my pragmatic hat on for now.

If I'm writing library or core system code, then it is vitally
important that the code coverage be as close to 100% as possible.

When I start at a new client and they have very few unit tests, I
switch into damage limitation/teaching mode and begin evangelising TDD
and unit testing, even though the code coverage might be so low that
it's laughable.

> In reality, we need to make compromises all the time and decide what part of
> our code we're not going to write tests for, so in effect, there *is* code
> that is too simple to be tested.

Pass-through methods are too simple to be tested on their own, but I
bet if you really tried hard, it could be done. It's all about the
"want to".

> More specifically in this article, I'm recommending that when you
> > find a bug, you write a test for it first, even if the fix is obvious.
> > The class in question had 100% code coverage before the bug was noticed.
> > 100% code coverage is practically a necessary but not sufficient
> > condition for bug free code.
>
>
> 100% code coverage is not just impossible to obtain and maintain, it's also
> deceptive and can make you think you are exercising your code in all
> possible ways. Which is, of course, never true.

Never say never. You have dismissed an absolute statement with an
absolute statement. That only works in political ad campaigns. (and
rebuttals to absolute statements :-)

100% code-coverage _is_ possible and is _always_ a worthy goal. Are
you always going to hit it? No, but that doesn't mean that you don't
try. It's about trying.

An example from one of my hobbies: target shooting with a .22 rifle. I
find that when I use large targets (1 inch diameter bulls eye) I shoot
at about upper 80's% accuracy. When I shoot with smaller targets (half
inch bulls eye), I shoot with lower 90's% accuracy. This seems
counter-intuitive, but I've done it often enough to know that it's
consistently true for me. The lesson that I have learned from this is
that the small target seems more difficult and so I try harder and
subsequently get a better result. The bigger target seems less of a
challenge, so I relax a little and my scores drop.

Here's a test you can try at home, even without a rifle: take a one
inch orange circle and place it somewhere at about chest height and
then walk 100 yards away from it, turn around and see how it looks. I
shoot with iron sights (that means no scope) and I get quite a few
9's, 10's and bulls eyes at 100 yards. Just because the target looks
very difficult, doesn't mean that you can't hit it (pun intended)!

In big or difficult systems, 100% code-coverage may seem impossible on
first consideration, but I'd bet that if you applied yourself, you'd
get closer than if you just tell yourself it's impossible and not even
try for it.

"Shoot for the moon ... land on the roof!" to quote a former co-worker of mine.

> If I have to choose between bumping my code coverage from 90% to 91% and
> writing a test that will exercise a documented feature, I will pick the
> latter any day.

Any test is better than none. Some code _deserves_ more tests. See
above comment about libraries and core code.
